utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We have a lot of very bright people in this caucus, and everybody knows it.
But it's very difficult to move up in an environment where the same people run everything all the time.
And you've seen this over the last few years.
A lot of House Democrats have just decided to run for other office or retire rather than wait around to advance up the ranks of leadership.
Right.

We should just point out, the younger generation of the House leadership on the Democratic side is, like, Steny Hoyer, who's - I can't remember how old he is; he is old - and people who've been around a really long time.
So when you think about how serious this threat is to Nancy Pelosi, I mean, is this a real risk?
Yeah.
The company says it will no longer post listings for homes that are open, apartments that are open in Israeli settlements in the West Bank.
This move comes amid pressure on companies to stop doing business there.
Israeli officials say they're being singled out and that they will take action against the company.

Well, likeability is this funny thing because voters, when you ask them, well, do you care about likeability, they say no, but there are these sort of emotional connections voters get with candidates, and they seem to have a problem with Hillary Clinton.

Having said that, there is some evidence that in some settings, when she actually gets a chance to present herself and not the caricature that has been put forward by her enemies or maybe some would say the media, she actually is able to convince people that she is likeable, or at least if not that, she would make a good president.

Isn't there some irony here, John, that women - these are sort of the so-called soft issues, the issues that women are naturally considered better at, the likeability, the warmth, the congeniality, the sort of first lady personality.
And Hillary Clinton has really done well on the stereotypical male attributes - strong foreign policy proposals, tough debater, that kind of thing.
That's right.
As one of her top aides said to me, it's kind of cool, she said, that Hillary wins all the guy categories.
If you look at the polling, it's extraordinary.
Democrats give her high marks, well above her opponents, on the questions of leadership, experience, skill in a crisis.
And in other polls you see independents, and even all voters, giving her higher leadership marks than someone like John McCain.

But then on the softer issues, yes, there is this question out there - the big question of the election will be whether voters really care and whether in a dangerous world, where there have been lots and lots of problems and will continue to be, whether voters really might more than in any other case before pay attention to those guy attributes, as Mrs. Clinton's staffer put it.
John Dickerson is the chief political correspondent for Slate.com.
His article on Hillary Clinton's Achilles heel is online now.
Thanks, John.
Thank you.
The U.S.
Olympic basketball team made headlines in 2004 for selfish play and bad behavior that undermined their game and their popularity among basketball fans.
But this year, Team USA has surprised commentator John McCann.
Maybe the mark of a world-class team really is good sportsmanship.
Wait a minute, now.
It ain't even supposed to work like this.
Any bootleg chemist will tell you that if you mix the NBA's cream of the crop and their millionaire mentalities and stir all that together with their big egos, then what you end with is a mess.
I mean that's how the brothers on the 2004 USA basketball team ended up with a bronze medal, right?
And we invented the game.
Well, a white dude actually invented the game, but the brothers made it more fun to watch with dunks and dipsy-do moves and all that.
But something happened since 2004, because that same chemistry experiment is having a different result.
Now maybe that's because USA basketball has a new chemist in basketball coach Mike Kryz - Coach K, all right.

See, the 2004 chemistry experiment turned out like the one you answered in to the elementary school science fair when you mixed vinegar and baking soda and stuff just bubbled up in to a great big glob of nothing much.
That's what all the egos and personal agendas amounted to a couple of years ago with USA basketball.
This time around is different.
The young hip-hoppers are on the same page, and it looks like alchemy isn't going to yield bronze this time but gold.
I guess watching what amounts to Goliath getting his butt kicked on the world stage will make you reevaluate some things and change your focus.
And maybe, just maybe, this is signaling to those of those in Generation X (unintelligible) about the need to reevaluate some things and change our focus about Generation Y and beyond.
You know, the super baggy pants wearing, show us your drawers us your drawers generation that doesn't have to comb their hair anymore because sticking on a do-rag covers their naps.
See, those are the kids that many people want to write-off and give up on.
We call them selfish and disrespectful and criticize their rap music.
And yet the parents of my peers have problems with what we were listening to.
I mean, is there really much difference between Nelly talking about his Nike Air Force Ones and me back in the day bobbing my head to Run DMC, kicking my Adidas.

Or for you older heads out there shaking your noggins at the sexually suggestive lyrics of today, do I need to tell you what Grace Jones was really talking about back in the day when she was singing about pulling up the bumpers and long black limousines?
Look, all I'm saying is maybe we're being too hard on the young kids coming up.
Now, don't misunderstand me.
Don't think I'm advocating that the young ones go out there and experiment with sex and them funny looking cigarettes and all that.
If you ask me, they all just need to get saved and live for the Lord.
But this USA basketball team is showing me that young people know how to get their act together, know how to get the job done when it's time show improve.
The hope is the younger cast looking up to LeBron James and Carmelo Anthony and them realize that they can cool and productive all at the same time.
John McCann is a columnist for The Herald-Sun in Durham, North Carolina.
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Alex Cohen.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
You know, no matter hard they try, police rarely get the upper hand on graffiti artists.
Well, now they've called in some high-tech help.
In the city of Pico Rivera, that's just east of L.A., police are using a digital camera with GPS to try to figure out where taggers will strike next.
NPR's Mandalit del Barco reports.
Along a hectic boulevard in Pico Rivera, a public works crew covers over the spray painted logos scrawled on the concrete.
Mr. MARCUS CAMPOS(ph) (Public Works Crew): They write over everything.
It's up to Marcus Campos to wipe out the calligraphy of local tagging crew GND.
GND has been around for years.
What does it stand for?
Graffiti Never Dies.
It is.
I mean - it's just on the verge of being very serious, as Steve pointed out.
There's an internal election next week where Democrats will vote behind closed doors.
Right now there's no question she'd win.
The question is - when there's a formal vote on the House floor, does she have the 218 votes she would need from Democrats to be elected?
There's a few races that still haven't been decided.
And right now, this letter is right on the verge of the amount of Democrats she can afford to lose...
Right.
...Which is interesting because all week, in the lead-up to this letter, the organizers had indicated the number would be much larger, something that would really prove she doesn't have the votes.
And right now, it's just on the border, though they point out there are several people committed to voting against her who have not signed their letter.
How's Pelosi responding to all this?
Pretty seriously.
At first, her camp really dismissed this - saying, this is nothing; of course Pelosi will be elected speaker.
But as time has gone on, you've seen her really take this seriously.
She's hold a lot of meetings with incoming Democrats.
She's very confident she has the support.
I interviewed her over the summer, and she said, if she's good at one thing, it's knowing exactly how many votes she has at any given time.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED BROADCAST)
I'm a numbers person.
When it comes to counting votes for legislation - passing the Affordable Care Act, the Recovery Act, the list goes on - Wall Street Reform and the rest.
And I'm a numbers person when it comes to my own possibilities in the Congress.
And you're hearing there her argument.
She's somebody who's gotten a lot of stuff done.
You look at how John Boehner and Paul Ryan have run the House since her, and they haven't gotten as much of their agenda passed as she was able to.
I mean, is it fair to say she's more threatened than she's ever been, though, for this job?
For sure.
And the next few weeks will be key.
Can she pick off some of the people who signed this list?
Can she get them to change their mind?
She's someone who has a lot of leverage and has a long track record of knowing how to use it.
Although, you point out, this is a question about who gets to go in what turn.
It's hard to identify the substantive, the issue on which a lot of Democrats would necessarily differ with Nancy Pelosi.
Although you have to point out - President Trump uses Nancy Pelosi as a foil, has for the last couple of years, even in the campaign.
And she would point out that Democrats are on the verge of picking up 40 seats after a campaign focused on her.
All right, NPR congressional correspondent Scott Detrow.
Thanks, Scott.
Thank you.

Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte welcomed China's President Xi Jingping.
The Philippines is a traditional U.S.
ally.
In fact, Americans used to run it.
